Pointers

  • single selectors on many elements will grab the first item of the list/array
  • multiple selectors do not have to access the global scope, they can be applied within a single selection (i.e. as a method of the querySelector() result)

Document Attributes

  • html-collections
    • an example would be querySelector() html-collections are not exactly arrays, but do have indexes and allow mehtods such as .length. When an array method is needed (as with .forEach() or .reverse() simply turn the collection into array via the Array.from('html_collection'). A better alternative would be...
  • node-lists
    • an example would be the value from querySelectorAll() these return arrays, useful when needing array methods without converting

DOM selectors

  • single selectors
    1. getElementById
  • multiple selectors
    1. getElementsByClassName()
    2. getElementsByTagName()

    which can be accessed by its index [n]

    and, 

        val = document;
        val = document.all;
        val = document.all[2]; //access the item via index
        val = document.all.length; // of the entire list
        val = document.head;
        val = document.body;
        val = document.doctype;
        val = document.domain; // for the actual domain, in our case localhost 127...
        val = document.URL; // domain with the protocol, port and file
        val = document.characterSet; //i.e. UTF-8
        val = document.contentType; //i.e. text/html
        
        val = document.forms;
        val = document.forms[0];
        val = document.forms[0].id;
        val = document.forms[0].method; // get
        val = document.forms[0].action; // returns the method if defined with action=""
        
        val = document.links;
        val = document.links[0];
        val = document.links[0].id; //if it has an id
        val = document.links[0].className;
        val = document.links[0].classList[0]; // returns a 'dom token list' of classes
        
        val = document.images;
        
        val = document.scripts;
        val = document.scripts[2].getAttribute("src"); // returns the actual file
        val = document.scripts[0].src; // will return the full path, protocol...

Event Changers

  • Changing styling
  • Changing content

When manipulating the document, several methods may be used with the 'getElementById()' selector.

  • .textContent
  • .innerText
  • .innerHTML
    • and a most popular with ES6
  • querySelector()
    • which allows us to use simple css syntax including nested elements and including pseudo classes!
However, almost always put the selector into a variable and apply the method on the variable name.
